gnat.client.nei
Class GenePubMedScorer

java.lang.Object
  gnat.client.nei.GenePubMedScorer

public class GenePubMedScorer
extends java.lang.Object

Scores one or more genes given their occurrence in a particular piece of text. Its main use is to rank a list of gene candidates, depending on which of them is more likely to be referred to in the text.

Scoring takes into consideration knowledge about each gene, such as

  • Gene Ontology terms associated with it,
  • sequence features such as length, domains, mutations,
  • protein mass
  • origin: species and chromosomal location,
  • protein interaction partners,
  • diseases associated with a gene,
  • etc.
These information are taken from GO/GOA, EntrezGene, UniProt, and other resources. For each gene, each type of information is sought in the given text and compared to the known data, resulting in a score and ranking per gene, depending on which gene's information most overlaps with the given text.

Author:
Joerg

NUMBER_OF_SCORES

public final int NUMBER_OF_SCORES
The number of sub-scores we currently calculate:
GO-term, GeneRIF, tissue spec, disease, EntrezGene summary, molecular weight, amino acids, chr. location, mutations, function, keywords, PubMed, protein domains.

finalize

public void finalize()
Call when not using the Scorer anymore. Closes the DB connection and writes new GO distances to the file go2gofile.

disambiguate

public Gene disambiguate(java.util.Collection<Gene> genes,
                         Text text)
Decides on a single Gene that best fits the given text. Decision is based on score (average and number of scored elements [GO terms, diseases, GeneRIFS, etc.]).

getScores

public java.util.LinkedList<java.lang.Float> getScores(Gene gene,
                                                       Text text,
                                                       java.lang.String geneName)
Returns a list of scores for scoring each context vector. Each score is between -1.0f and 1.0f. Some entries in the list might be null, when the gene did not have a corresponding context vector;
